question: The dangers of smoking are well known, yet many people continue with this habit.What are the causes of this? How can we reduce smoking in society?Give reasons for your answer, and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
human: It is very easy to find someone who smokes in today's society. Even though we were taught that smoke is harmful, we see people exhaling this thick fog everyday partly because some people think that it is cool and it can be purchased almost at every store. This essay will discuss deeply about what causes people to smoke and how this issue can be alleviated.Firstly, part of the society believes that it is trendy to smoke. In many pop culture, such as songs, movies, and novels portray smoking possitively. A comedy show that I have seen illustrates one of the character that smokes to be more cool, giving this character an untouchable aura, whilst other characters that did not smoke seem tangible and therefore mundane. Furthermore, cigarettes are easily accessable in any store. A recent study proved that over 80% of those eager to smoke for the first time actually started this behavior because they can buy it from their local shops. The trend from pop culture and the convenience in accessing smoke adds up to the reasons why some people continues with this habit.I believe that there are solutions that can tackle and reduce smoking, beginning with medias should portray smoking to have consequences that are relatable. A movie I have seen showed the protagonist's constant need for cigarette throughout the show. However, in the end when he finally unites with his crush, he develops a severe disease, mainly from his smoking habits, in which he regretted in the end. This method of portraying people who smoke totally made my younger niece scared of smoking. In addition, government should control the accessibility of cigarettes. Policies that result and fewer stores being able to sell cigarettes and increasing tax pricing of smoke of any kind will definitely make smoking less convenient for many people.In conclusion, although many people knew how harmful smoking is, many people think it is cool to smoke and it is convenient and easy to buy. By making smoking less trendy in society and harder to access, I believe that smoking will be less attractive, hence reducing the number of smokers in society.
llm: Smoking is a pervasive habit in today's society, despite the well-known risks associated with it. The ease of access to cigarettes, combined with the glamorization of smoking in popular culture, has contributed to its widespread adoption. This essay will delve into the reasons behind smoking and explore potential solutions to mitigate this issue.One of the primary factors contributing to smoking is the perception that it is trendy and cool. Popular culture, including songs, movies, and novels, often portrays smoking in a positive light. For instance, a comedy show I watched featured a character who smoked, giving them an air of sophistication and invincibility, while non-smoking characters appeared ordinary and unremarkable. Furthermore, the widespread availability of cigarettes in stores has made it easy for people to start smoking. A recent study revealed that over 80% of first-time smokers were motivated to try cigarettes because they were readily available at local shops. The combination of pop culture's glorification of smoking and the convenience of accessing cigarettes has led many people to adopt this habit.However, I believe that there are effective ways to address and reduce smoking. One approach is for the media to depict the consequences of smoking in a realistic and relatable manner. A movie I watched, for example, showed the protagonist's constant craving for cigarettes, but ultimately, his smoking habit led to a severe disease, which he deeply regretted. This portrayal of smoking was so impactful that it scared my younger niece away from the idea of smoking. Additionally, governments should restrict access to cigarettes by implementing policies that limit the number of stores that can sell them and increasing taxes on tobacco products. By making smoking less convenient and less glamorous, I believe that its appeal will diminish, leading to a reduction in the number of smokers in society.In conclusion, despite the well-documented risks of smoking, many people still perceive it as cool and convenient. By making smoking less trendy and less accessible, I firmly believe that its allure will decrease, resulting in a decrease in the number of smokers in society.

question: The diagram below show the development of the horse over a period of 40 million years. The evolution of the horse, with particular emphasis on the changing foot structure.Write a report for a university lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The diagram illustrates the evolution of the horse in terms of their foot structure over a 40 million year period. Overall, the horse's were divided into four stages of development, starting from a period of 40 million years ago until now, with a 10 to 15 million year gap approximation in between.To begin with, 40 million years ago, the Eohippus, which was the first developmental stage of a horse's foot structure was similar to the bone structure of a human's hand. However, they branch out into five toes while travelling on foot. Then, during stage 2 of the horse's foot development, which was 10 million years later, the horse evolved into a Mesohippus. With regards to the structure of its toe, it was reduced from the original five into three. In addition, the middle toe had a larger foot structure compared to other other two.Next, 15 million years later, came the evolution of a Merychippus from a Mesohippus. Similarly, the foot structure was identical to the Mesohippus' horse but did not have the middle toe's length significantly longer than the other two. Although the middle toe was thicker than before, it became more even in terms of its length comparison to its other two toes. Finally, the emergence of the final evolution of the horse in modern days. With regards to the foot structure, it no longer branched out into several toes as it used to be, but is shaped like a tree branch with a rounded bases on the bottom of the foot.
llm: The diagram depicts the evolution of the horse's foot structure over a period of 40 million years, divided into four distinct stages. The development stages are separated by approximately 10 to 15 million year gaps.The first stage, which occurred 40 million years ago, is represented by the Eohippus. At this stage, the horse's foot structure was similar to that of a human hand, with five toes that branched out as the horse moved. 10 million years later, during the second stage, the horse evolved into a Mesohippus. The toe structure was reduced from five to three, with the middle toe being significantly larger than the other two.The third stage occurred 15 million years later, with the emergence of the Merychippus from the Mesohippus. The foot structure of the Merychippus was similar to that of the Mesohippus, but with a notable difference: the middle toe was no longer significantly longer than the other two toes. Although it was thicker, its length was more even compared to the other two toes.Finally, the fourth and final stage of evolution is represented by the modern horse. In contrast to its predecessors, the horse's foot structure no longer branches out into multiple toes. Instead, it has a single, tree-branch-like shape with a rounded base on the bottom of the foot, marking the culmination of the horse's 40 million year evolutionary journey.

question: The diagram below shows how Olive Oil is manufactured.Write a report for a university lecturer describing the information below.
human: The Olive Oil is manufactured through several ways. First of all, the olives are picked from the trees by the farmers. Then the fresh olives are rinished using the cold water. The machines used are specific and it helps belt to smash the olives. After smashed, the olives become either olive paster or the olive stones. The next step is to put those into a bag with holes. Moving onto the next step, it will be pressed by a certain pressurer. It gives a great amount of weight on the olives so that it can be well pressed. Moreover it will be separated into either oil or water. Then, it will be stored and sold to the consumers. Thus, it is quite apparent that olive oil is manufactured by specific steps. And so more, olive oil is widely used as it is a good source for the chefs when cooking.
llm: Olive oil is produced through a multi-step process. First, farmers harvest olives from trees. Next, the fresh olives are washed with cold water. Specialized machines are used to crush the olives, which helps to release their contents. After crushing, the olives are separated into either olive paste or pits. The olive paste is then placed in a bag with holes, allowing for the next step in the process. The bag is subjected to a significant amount of pressure from a specialized press, which extracts the liquid from the olives. The resulting liquid is then separated into oil and water. Finally, the olive oil is stored and sold to consumers. It is clear that the production of olive oil involves a series of specific steps. Additionally, olive oil is widely used due to its numerous benefits, making it a valuable resource for chefs in the kitchen.

question: The diagram below shows how coffee is produced and prepared for sale in supermarkets and shops.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The diagram shows the process of coffee from production to preparing for sale in supermarkets and shops.Overall, it is certain that coffee goes through 11 different stages from picking the beans to packing in jars.Firstly, coffee beans are picked and then dried by humans. The dried beans are later roasted in a machine then in the blast freezer machine, it's cooled down rapidly. Furthermore, after cooling out they go through a grinding process where they turned into powder, then mixed with high-temperature water after a while, it goes from straining process.We are now arriving at the later process where coffee is now frozen in the refrigerator. In total,,assistantThe diagram illustrates the coffee production process, from harvesting to packaging for sale in supermarkets and shops. In total, coffee undergoes 11 distinct stages, from bean picking to jar packing.The process begins with the manual picking and drying of coffee beans by humans. The dried beans are then roasted in a machine and rapidly cooled in a blast freezer. After cooling, the beans are ground into a powder and mixed with hot water. Following this, the mixture undergoes a straining process.The latter stages of the process involve freezing the coffee in a refrigerator. In the third-to-last stage, the frozen coffee is reground, and then placed in a vacuum machine, where the water is evaporated to dry the coffee.Finally, the coffee is prepared for packaging in jars and is ready for sale in the market.

question: The diagram below shows how oil is expected in use of production of perfumeSummarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The given process chart illustrates how perfume is obtained using oil as an ingredient. Overall, the product undergoes 4 main steps, which involve prevalently water and the usage of heating and cooling down methods, in addition to a separation machine, before being ready to be used to create a fragrance.For starters, the water is placed in a metal tank and brought to the boiling point through direct flames. Then, the steam is conducted by a pipe to another cistern, where aromatic plants are added, in order to obtain oil vapor mixed with steam.Right afterward, the mixture goes into a pipe system, where a condensation process takes place, thanks to a condenser that uses cold water. In doing so, the cold water flowing in the condenser absorbs the heat that comes from the pipe where the oil and water solution is. After that, water mixed with essential oil reaches the last tank, in which a separator proceeds to take essential oil apart. This way, only the aromatic water is able to proceed and it is possible to use it in the perfume industry.
llm: The process chart shows how perfume is produced using oil as a key ingredient. The production process involves four main stages, which primarily utilize water and employ heating and cooling methods, as well as a separation machine, to create a fragrance-ready product.Firstly, water is placed in a metal tank and heated to its boiling point using direct flames. The resulting steam is then directed through a pipe to another tank, where aromatic plants are added to produce a mixture of oil vapor and steam.Next, the mixture enters a piping system, where it undergoes condensation through a condenser that uses cold water. As the cold water flows through the condenser, it absorbs the heat from the pipe carrying the oil and water solution. After condensation, the water mixed with essential oil flows into a final tank, where a separator is used to isolate the essential oil. This process allows only the aromatic water to proceed, making it suitable for use in the perfume industry.

question: The diagram below shows how rain water is collected and then treated to be used as drinking water in an Australian town. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.You should write at least 150 words.
human: Information is presented in a diagram which depicts the main steps of rainwater treatment with the aim to produce drinking water in a particular town in Australia.Overall, it can be clearly seen that the process involves a number of complex stages starting from collecting rainwater, purification until getting the water as a final product.At the beginning of the process, rainwater is drained from a roof through a tube which is attached to each house. Then the water flow through the tube to a three-layer water filter which is the first step of water purification. After that, the filtered water is kept in a storage tank which is connected to a water treatment tank. As the water in the storage flows into the water treatment tank, it is mixed with chemicals, making this step as the final part of the process. Once the water is mixed, it flows from the water treatment tank to each house and is ready for drinking.
llm: A diagram illustrates the key stages of rainwater treatment in a specific Australian town, with the goal of producing drinking water. The process encompasses multiple intricate steps, from collection to purification, ultimately yielding a final product. The treatment process begins with the collection of rainwater from rooftops, which is then channeled through a tube connected to each house. The collected rainwater flows through this tube into a three-layer water filter, marking the initial stage of purification. Following filtration, the water is stored in a tank linked to a water treatment facility. As the stored water flows into the treatment tank, it is blended with chemicals, constituting the final phase of the treatment process. Once the water has been treated, it flows from the treatment tank back to each household, ready for consumption.

question: The diagram below shows how solar panels can be used to provide electricity for domestic use.Write a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The diagram illustrates the production of electricity for domestic use by solar panels. Overall, electricity is provided after it has been processed using 5 equipments ( solar panels, inverter electrical panel, utility meter and utility grid).First of all, solar panels on the roof of a normal house receive and absorb energy from the sun and turn it into DC current. The second stage is that, the DC current is converted into AC current by using inverter, which controls the electricity and production. After that, once the solar electricity has been distributed to our homes, it is then flowed back to the grid through a utility meter.At the final stage of the process, a utility grid, which looks like a small electrical tower, provides electricity when an user uses extra amount than the amount produced by the solar panles. By these stages, electricity is produced and ready for domestic use.
llm: The diagram depicts the process of generating electricity for domestic use through solar panels. The production of electricity involves five key components: solar panels, an inverter, an electrical panel, a utility meter, and a utility grid.The process begins with solar panels installed on the roof of a typical household, which capture and absorb sunlight, converting it into direct current (DC) electricity. The next stage involves the conversion of DC current into alternating current (AC) using an inverter, which regulates and controls the flow of electricity.Once the solar-generated electricity is distributed to homes, any excess energy is fed back into the grid through a utility meter. This meter measures the amount of electricity produced by the solar panels and the amount consumed by the household.In the final stage, the utility grid, resembling a small electrical tower, plays a crucial role in supplementing the solar power when the household's energy consumption exceeds the amount produced by the solar panels. Through these stages, electricity is generated and made available for domestic use, providing a reliable and efficient source of power.

Furthermore, the amount of time spent on unpaid work by married men remains relatively constant across the different categories, showing no significant variation.

question: The diagram below shows the life cycle of a salmon, from egg to adult fish.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The diagram depicts the life-cycle of the salmon, from being an egg to transforming into a fully grown adult fish.The first stage of the salmon starts in the river, where the spawning of two mature salmons lead to the laying of eggs. The rivers have long been chosen by salmons for breeding spots because their fresh-saltless water is suitable for the eggs and the freshly hatched baby salmons to start maturing in. After emerging from the eggs, the hatchlings stay on in the fresh water till they pre-mature/partially grow. After gaining considerable size and adapting to the primary waters, they travel to the estuaries, the only stop-over between them and the oceans. Only the first of the young salmons to reach the estuaries are able to make it to the oceans. This is because once these small and stagnant water bodies get over-crowded, there is virtually no space left in them which in-turn leads to the death of many young salmons.The young salmons who were able to survive the estuaries journey to the oceans, where the salty water increases their size and makes them fully grown. After getting the maturity to breed, they go back to the rivers from where the cycle starts all-over again.In total, there are 8 stages in the life of a salmon to maturity, it starts in the rivers and ends in the rivers too.
llm: The diagram illustrates the life cycle of a salmon, from its initial stage as an egg to its development into a fully grown adult fish. The life cycle of a salmon begins in a river, where two mature salmon spawn, resulting in the laying of eggs. Rivers have been chosen by salmon as breeding grounds due to their freshwater, which is ideal for the eggs and newly hatched salmon to mature. After hatching, the young salmon, known as hatchlings, remain in the freshwater until they partially grow. Once they have gained significant size and adapted to the freshwater, they migrate to the estuaries, a transitional zone between the river and the ocean. However, only the first batch of young salmon to reach the estuaries can successfully make it to the ocean, as the estuaries can become overcrowded, leading to the death of many young salmon.The young salmon that survive the estuaries journey then migrate to the ocean, where the salty water facilitates their growth into fully grown adults. Upon reaching maturity, they return to the river where their life cycle initially began, marking the start of a new cycle. In total, a salmon's life cycle consists of 8 stages, from its birth in the river to its return to the river as a mature adult, ready to begin the cycle anew.

question: The diagram below shows the life cycle of the honey bee.Write a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.

This process lasts around 34 to 36 days and it repeats itself over again.The cycle starts when female bees lay their eggs. They lay their eggs rapidly but surely at around 1 or 2 eggs every 3 days. Subsequently the hatching of the eggs happens after 9 to 10 days.Afterwards the nymph molts begin to come out of the eggs and keep on gradually growing up until the 7th day of the cycle. During their 9th day, the bees grow 3 times their initial size. Following this, the young adult emerges. The final step occurs after 4 days when the bee reaches its maturity and females are ready to lay eggs again. Making the cycle begin again from the laying of the eggs.
llm: The life cycle of a honey bee can be broken down into six stages, which are categorized into two main phases: hatching and maturation. This entire process typically lasts between 34 to 36 days and is a recurring cycle.The cycle commences with female bees laying eggs at a rate of approximately 1 or 2 eggs every 3 days. After 9 to 10 days, these eggs hatch, marking the beginning of the next stage.Following hatching, the nymphs emerge from the eggs and undergo gradual growth until around the 7th day of the cycle. By the 9th day, these young bees have grown to three times their initial size. Shortly after, they emerge as young adults.The final stage of the cycle occurs 4 days later, when the bee reaches full maturity. At this point, female bees are ready to lay eggs, thus initiating the cycle anew, starting with the laying of eggs. This repetitive process ensures the continuous development and growth of the honey bee colony.

question: The diagram below shows the production of olive oil. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.You should write at least 150 words.
human: This illust displays all the procedures by which olive oil is produced from olives. There is a total of seven steps where the initial step is to pick some olives, and the final step is to extract only olive oil from pressed olive paste.To put into detail, obtaining enough amounts of olive is the starting process. Picked olives are rinsed in cold water. After that, rinsed olives are delivered into a smashing machine through belts. This machine enables olives to divide into olive paste and olive stones. Thereafter, only olive paste is put into hollow bags and carried into the pressing process. Olive paste inside the bag is pressed and further move into separating process. This is the complete process of olive oil production.

Once gathered, the olives are washed in cold water to remove any dirt or debris. Next, they are transported via conveyor belts to a crushing machine, which breaks down the olives into a paste and separates the stones. The resulting olive paste is then placed into perforated bags, which are taken to the pressing stage. During this stage, the olive paste is subjected to pressure, which helps to release the oil, and this mixture then moves on to the separation stage. Here, a portion of the oil is fully separated from the water content, resulting in pure olive oil. Finally, the extracted olive oil is stored and, if necessary, distributed to the market. This comprehensive process encompasses the production of olive oil from start to finish.

question: The diagram shows the components of a neuron and how it worksWrite a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The diagram below identifies the role of each neuronal components and illustrates the message transmission process happening in a neuron.The main component of a neuron is the cell body or soma. From its core branches out many small nerves called dendrites with the role of receving messages from other cells. The acquired messages are passed away from the cell body to other neurons, muscles or glands through a chain of axon. Each axon is coverred by a small element called myelin sheath that helps speed up the neural impulses.The message transmission process is conducted by continous actions of each component. After the dendrites receive information, the cell body will trigger an electrical signal traveling down the axon chain carrying these messages to a destination consisting of a network off terminal buttons. llm: The following diagram highlights the function of each neuronal component and demonstrates the process of message transmission within a neuron.The cell body, also known as the soma, is the primary component of a neuron. Extending from the cell body are numerous small nerve fibers called dendrites, which are responsible for receiving messages from other cells. These received messages are then transmitted away from the cell body to other neurons, muscles, or glands via a chain of axons. Each axon is coated with a thin layer called the myelin sheath, which facilitates the rapid transmission of neural impulses.The message transmission process is facilitated by the continuous actions of each component. Once the dendrites receive information, the cell body initiates an electrical signal that travels down the axon chain, conveying the messages to a destination comprising a network of terminal buttons. Each button forms a junction with the dendrites of other cells, enabling the connection of messages. Ultimately, all neurons are interconnected to form a complex network.

Similarly, Far east and Australian subbranches also divides into two subbranches (Malay and chinese, and Australian and Newzealand respectively). West african, Angelophones and East African are three languages that belong to the African Subbranch. Last two subbranches - Indian pakistan and British Isles each divide into four types of languages, British Isles into Irish, English, Welsh and Scotish, and Indian Pakistan into four different forms of indian english.
llm: This diagram depicts the relationships between various types of English languages, highlighting the connections between American English and British English, as well as their respective subbranches.At the highest level, the English language is divided into two primary branches: American English and British English. British English, in particular, has a more complex structure with a greater number of subbranches compared to American English.American English is subdivided into two main subbranches: the United States and Canada. The Canadian subbranch is further divided into two distinct types: Anglophone Canadian and Francophone Canadian. In contrast, the United States subbranch is more diverse, branching out into six distinct types, including those spoken in the Philippines, American Samoa, the West Coast, the Midwest, the Northeast Coast, and Puerto Rico.British English, on the other hand, exhibits a more extensive branching pattern, with three times as many subbranches as American English. One of its subbranches is the West Indies, which splits into Jamaican and Barbadian. Similarly, the Far East and Australian subbranches each divide into two subcategories: Malay and Chinese for the Far East, and Australian and New Zealand for the Australian subbranch. The African subbranch comprises West African, Anglophone, and East African languages. The last two subbranches, Indian Pakistan and British Isles, each subdivide into four distinct languages. The British Isles branch separates into Irish, English, Welsh, and Scottish, while the Indian Pakistan branch diversifies into four unique forms of Indian English.

question: The diagrams below show how houses can be protected in areas which are prone to flooding.Write a report for a university, lecturer describing the information shown below.
human: The schemes compare two different methods of defence for homes that can be easily affected by floods. Overall, they show flood protection with and without a stopbank, while the at-risk home is raised higher above ground level in two pictures.The first diagram depicts how a stopbank acts as a natural barrier to prevent river water from flooding. The stopbank is a small mound of land next to the river that is higher than the 100-year-flood level and prevents the drain from overwhelming its banks. Nearby buildings can be built on stilts to prevent flooding from rainwater as well as the water passing through the floodgate beneath the stopbank, resulting in an area of ‘internal ponding.’If it had not been a stopbank, as described in the second diagram, there would have been nothing to stop the river from flooding. In this case, the solution is to put homes on stilts much higher than the one in the first picture. The height of the stilts is measured to ensure that the floor of the house is three hundred meters above the 100-year-flood level regardless of how deep the water area is under the house. This measure is called the ‘freeboard.’
llm: The schemes illustrate two distinct approaches to defending homes that are prone to flooding. They demonstrate flood protection with and without a stopbank, while also showing a home elevated higher above ground level in two separate scenarios.The first illustration explains how a stopbank functions as a natural barrier to prevent flooding from river water. The stopbank is a raised mound of land adjacent to the river, designed to be higher than the 100-year-flood level, thereby preventing the river from overflowing its banks. Nearby homes can be built on stilts to protect against flooding from both rainwater and the water flowing under the stopbank through a floodgate, which can create an area of "internal ponding" around the home.In contrast, the second diagram depicts a scenario without a stopbank, where the river would be able to flood freely. To mitigate this, homes are built on stilts that are significantly higher than those in the first scenario. The height of these stilts is carefully calculated to ensure that the floor of the house is at least 300 meters above the 100-year-flood level, regardless of the water depth beneath the house. This safety margin is referred to as the "freeboard".

llm: Initially, the image depicts a wave-energy machine, which is equipped with an electricity generator. This machine harnesses energy from waves and features two turbines, allowing air to flow through them. Upon closer inspection, it appears that there are two types of wave energy machines: one designed for large waves and another for small waves.Furthermore, the smaller wave machine has a lower output, as it is intended for smaller waves. Additionally, it has lower installation costs due to its smaller size. In contrast, the larger wave machine has a higher output, but also comes with higher installation costs due to its larger size.In summary, the air flows through the turbine, causing it to move and generate electricity. question: The diagrams below show the development of the horse over a period of 40 million years.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant
human: The diagram depicts the different stages of the body habitus and the relative changes in foot structures that under went in the process of evolution of the modern horse, since 40 million years ago.The modern horse had gone through 3 main stages in order to become it's current version, each stage shows distinctive changes in the body as a whole.Having said that, the earliest species that existed is namely Echippus, then it was mesohippus and finally it was Merychippus.The Echippus is the identified first ancestor of the modern horse that existed 40 million years ago. They appeared relatively similar to the size of a sheep and their foot apearently had four toes.However, Mesohippus was the second in line of the modern horses and was relatively bigger and taller, the foot structure got limited to three toes and the middle toe being the widerest.15 million years after the existance of mesohippus, merychippus emerged, they were similar in both the size and shape of our modern horses, but as far as the foot is concerned the middle toe became more prominent and the rest two toes started to shrink. Finally, the modern horses look twice the size of Echippus and their feet looked proper coronet.
llm: The diagram illustrates the various stages of body habitus and the corresponding changes in foot structure that occurred during the 40 million year evolution of the modern horse. This process involved three main stages, each characterized by distinct transformations in the body as a whole. The ancestral lineage of the modern horse is comprised of three notable species: Echippus, Mesohippus, and Merychippus.Echippus, the earliest identified ancestor of the modern horse, existed approximately 40 million years ago. It was relatively small, similar in size to a sheep, and had a foot structure with four toes. In contrast, Mesohippus, which emerged later, was larger and taller, with a foot structure that had reduced to three toes, and a wider middle toe.Merychippus, which appeared 15 million years after Mesohippus, was similar in size and shape to modern horses. However, its foot structure showed significant changes, with the middle toe becoming more prominent and the other two toes starting to shrink. Ultimately, the modern horse evolved to be roughly twice the size of Echippus, with a foot structure that resembled a proper coronet, marking the culmination of this evolutionary process.

The living room is currently smaller than in the proposed new plan, which suggests increasing its size by demolishing an internal wall. The single door will be replaced with a double door, which will be relocated near the entrance. The kitchen furniture will be positioned on the opposite side of the wall, adjacent to the doubled indoor door. Nevertheless, some aspects of the original plan will remain intact, including the locations of the front and backyard entrance doors, as well as the wall separating the hall and kitchen.

question: The diagrams below show the water supply system in Australia present and in future.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The given diagram illustrates the processes involved in the water supply system in Australia at the present and in the future.To begin, the first kind of water is located in the dam and storage where the waste water is lead to a water treatment plant. Meanwhile, from the storage come out pure water and provide potable water to households, factories, shops, and all the city. At the same time, the wastewater produced in the city is transferred to a water treatment plant as well.The last type of water is the storm water that is sent to the river from the city.Overall, it can be seen that the process has three types of waters in the process of water supply which are pure, storm, and waste water. depending on the type of water, these can be found in the dam and storage, water treatment plant, river and in different places of the city such as households, factories, shops, among others.
llm: The provided diagram depicts the current and future processes involved in Australia's water supply system. The process begins with water stored in dams and reservoirs, from which wastewater is directed to a water treatment plant. Simultaneously, treated water from the storage facilities is distributed as potable water to various sectors of the city, including households, factories, and shops. Additionally, wastewater generated within the city is also channeled to a water treatment plant for processing.Lastly, stormwater from the city is diverted to rivers. In summary, the water supply process encompasses three primary types of water: pure water, stormwater, and wastewater. These types of water can be found in various locations, including dams, storage facilities, water treatment plants, rivers, and different parts of the city such as homes, industrial areas, and commercial establishments.

llm: The diagram provides a detailed illustration of the construction of a solar panel and the intricate process by which it supplies heated water and air to homes, serving as a renewable energy source.The initial diagram offers a visual representation of the solar panel's basic structure. Essentially, it consists of a large container with two pipes, one on each side, and a similarly sized transparent top that is placed over the container.As shown in the second diagram, the solar panel is engineered to warm the air within a home. The process begins with cold air entering through an inlet into the box. The transparent top of the panel then allows sunlight to warm the air through its heating properties. The process involves water entering through an inlet, passing through the pipes where it is heated, and then exiting, thereby supplying hot water to homes.

question: The education system is the only critical factor in the development of a country, agree/disagree (from Target Band
human: This essay was written on a topic from “Target Band 7” book (page 54, reprinted with permission).You should spend about 40 minutes on this taskSome people say that the education system is the only critical factor in the development of a country. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?Write at least 250 wordsEducation plays an imperative role in the overall progression of a country. Many people may heavily rely on quality education as preparation for real life employment and experiences. However, there are other factors that are needed to propel a country towards success.We must acknowledge the way the education system of a country prepares most individuals by equipping them with various skills. Prior to gaining a qualification to practice certain professions such as teaching, nursing or accounting, it is necessary for the individuals to undergo rigorous training. Certificate and diploma programs as well as university degrees are good examples of that. Some graduates may even choose to pursue further studies to attain certain requirements to be able to practice their chosen profession.The education system is undoubtedly important in preparing individuals to take on roles leading to the development of a country. However, it seems that producing graduates alone isn’t a guarantee of the advancement of a country. There are other factors that should come into play, and motivation of individuals is one. Without motivation, people may lose track of what they intend to do to contribute to the improvement of a country. drives people to achieve and maximize their potentials, because they are determined to get better at many aspects of their life, eventually yielding improvement for their entire country.Furthermore, the availability of natural resources and job opportunities may also affect the growth of a national economy. Innovations of many individuals require raw materials, and should the country be able to mine these, their production and perhaps even export may help in stabilizing the local market. Finally, it is also important that the availability of employment is aligned with the skills of individuals applying for the positions. Giving skilled people the opportunity to apply their knowledge and experience in their profession makes them more productive, which contributes to GDP growth.In conclusion, education continues to play a pivotal role in the development of a country. However, other important factors should play a role in order to achieve steady and continuous progress.This response adequately addresses the task prompt. The writer’s viewpoint is clear throughout the essay. Each paragraph has its role and they are used effectively to organise ideas and information. The coherence and advanced vocabulary help the writer to create an impression of a skilled, fluent English user. Good control of grammar and punctuation is evident. This essay could achieve Band 8 in IELTS.
llm: This essay, originally published in the "Target Band 7" book (page 54, reprinted with permission), tackles a topic that requires approximately 40 minutes to complete. The statement that the education system is the sole critical factor in a country's development sparks a debate. In this essay, we will explore the extent to which one agrees or disagrees with this assertion.Education undeniably plays a vital role in a country's overall progress. Many individuals rely heavily on quality education as a preparation for real-life employment and experiences. However, there are other essential factors necessary to propel a country towards success. The education system prepares individuals by equipping them with various skills. Before gaining qualifications to practice certain professions, such as teaching, nursing, or accounting, individuals must undergo rigorous training. Certificate and diploma programs, as well as university degrees, exemplify this. Some graduates may even choose to pursue further studies to meet specific requirements for their chosen profession.The education system is crucial in preparing individuals for roles that contribute to a country's development. Nevertheless, producing graduates alone does not guarantee a country's advancement. Other factors, such as individual motivation, should come into play. Without motivation, people may lose sight of their goals to contribute to a country's improvement. Motivation drives individuals to achieve and maximize their potential, ultimately leading to improvement for the entire country.Additionally, the availability of natural resources and job opportunities can impact a national economy's growth. Innovations require raw materials, and if a country can mine these resources, production and potential export can help stabilize the local market. It is also essential that job availability aligns with the skills of individuals applying for positions. Providing skilled individuals with the opportunity to apply their knowledge and experience in their profession makes them more productive, contributing to GDP growth.In conclusion, education continues to play a pivotal role in a country's development. However, other important factors must also be considered to achieve steady and continuous progress. This essay effectively addresses the task prompt, with the writer's viewpoint clear throughout. Each paragraph serves a purpose, organizing ideas and information effectively. The coherence and advanced vocabulary create an impression of a skilled, fluent English user. Good control of grammar and punctuation is evident, making this essay a potential Band 8 scorer in IELTS.

question: The end of the world’s fossil fuel resources and the subsequent changes will be a positive development in society. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: Today’s society overwhelmingly depends on products made from fossil fuels. Most people would initially think about fuel for transport, but of course, fossil fuels are part of most of the fabric of life around us, from the plastics on our furniture to the pavements that we walk on. Changing our reliance on these resources can have various consequences; however, I believe that overall the society will benefit from finding viable alternatives for them.Depending on whether eco-friendly alternatives are developed, the positive effect on transport and the reduction of the associated pollution will be significant. Exhaust fumes from motor vehicles, planes and ships decrease air quality and contribute to global warming and the greenhouse effect. People’s health and the health of the planet will surely improve without these industries relying on fossil fuels. It could be that a type of transport crisis could develop as a result if society can no longer provide the power to transport so many individuals to where they want to go. This, however, does not have to be a bad thing, as it could force society to use alternative solutions, such as transport sharing and public transport development. The change in mind set has already begun. Some countries have already committed to having fossil fuel free transport and more cities are banning private vehicles from the centre of cities.Another positive development would be that more time and money would have to be put into developing renewable sources of energy, such as wind power, solar power, hydropower and tidal power. Technologies would improve and be more efficient and again, the world would use fewer sources of energy that cause pollution. This development can also be seen today, with many governments committing to proportions of their power needs coming from renewable resources.I, therefore, strongly agree with the statement that the changes from reducing reliance on fossil fuels will be positive. The only caveat is that society will need to have developed alternative sources of power rather soon, in order to avoid an energy crisis.
llm: Our modern society is heavily reliant on products derived from fossil fuels, which are deeply ingrained in our daily lives, from the plastics in our furniture to the roads we walk on. Shifting away from this dependence can have far-reaching consequences, but I firmly believe that finding alternative solutions will ultimately benefit society as a whole. The development of eco-friendly alternatives will significantly reduce pollution from transportation, such as exhaust fumes from cars, planes, and ships, which currently degrade air quality and contribute to global warming. This, in turn, will lead to improved public health and a healthier planet. However, a potential transport crisis may arise if fossil fuels are no longer available to power the large-scale transportation of people. On the other hand, this could prompt society to adopt alternative solutions like car-sharing and enhanced public transportation systems. In fact, this shift in mindset has already begun, with some countries pledging to achieve fossil fuel-free transportation and cities banning private vehicles from their centers.Another advantage of reducing our reliance on fossil fuels is the increased investment in renewable energy sources, such as wind, solar, hydro, and tidal power. As technology advances and becomes more efficient, the world will move away from polluting energy sources. This trend is already visible, with many governments committing to generate a significant portion of their energy needs from renewable resources.In conclusion, I strongly support the idea that decreasing our dependence on fossil fuels will have a positive impact. The only condition is that society must develop alternative energy sources relatively quickly to avoid an energy crisis. Overall, I believe that the benefits of transitioning away from fossil fuels far outweigh the potential drawbacks, and I am optimistic about the positive changes that this shift will bring about.

question: The fact that enormous sums are paid for pieces of art is not acceptable at a time when many people around the world live in poverty. Discuss this statement and give your opinion.Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: It is true that pieces of art in today’s world can change hands for enormous sums. Works by artists such as Picasso, da Vinci and Rembrandt have been sold for millions of dollars. Recently, a Modigliani was sold to a billionaire for one hundred and seventy million dollars. It certainly seems obscene that such figures are spent when many people around the world live in poverty.The work of many charities would be transformed by the money generated by just one of these art sales and in turn, the lives of ordinary people in need would be transformed. Medicines, food and shelter amongst other things could easily be provided, saving lots of lives, many of which would be children. When the issue is looked at from this point of view, the art sales world certainly seems obscene.However, in my opinion, things are unlikely to change. Human greed is endemic and people who have the drive to earn that amount of money and who actually have access to these sums in cash are not often people who will part with their wealth. Lots of prosperous people support many charities, but it is unlikely that they would completely relinquish their access to the luxuries that accompany their lives. The works of art are also often seen as investments in themselves, to be held on to for a period of time and then resold at a profit.In conclusion, in an ideal world, the vast sums of money that are spent on fine and rare works of art would be better spent on helping those in need. In reality, however, this is unlikely to take place.
llm: The art market has become a multi-million dollar industry, with pieces by renowned artists like Picasso, da Vinci, and Rembrandt being sold for staggering sums. A recent example is the sale of a Modigliani to a billionaire for a whopping $170 million. This raises questions about the morality of spending such enormous amounts on art when millions of people worldwide live in poverty. The proceeds from just one of these sales could drastically impact the work of charities and, in turn, transform the lives of those in need, providing essential necessities like medicine, food, and shelter, and saving countless lives, including those of children. From this perspective, the art sales world appears excessively extravagant. However, I believe that change is unlikely. Human greed is pervasive, and individuals who have amassed enormous wealth and have the means to acquire these expensive artworks are often reluctant to part with their riches. While many affluent individuals do support charitable causes, few are willing to sacrifice the luxuries that come with their wealth. Additionally, these artworks are frequently viewed as investments, meant to be held onto for a period before being resold for a profit.In an ideal world, the vast sums spent on rare and fine artworks would be better allocated towards aiding those in need. Unfortunately, reality suggests that this is unlikely to happen. The allure of wealth and the investment potential of art will likely continue to drive the market, leaving the disparity between excessive spending on art and the needs of the impoverished unchanged.

question: The flow chart below shows an automatic photo booth. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.You should write at least 150 words.

Be seated if you are ready for the shot. Sit straight and wait for light signal flash after 3 seconds. llm: To use the automatic photo booth, simply insert the required number of coins and choose between colour or black and white photos on the control panel. Use the mirror above the camera to make any necessary adjustments to your hair and face before taking the photo.Before the photo is taken, make sure the curtain is fully closed. Sit up straight and wait for the signal. The camera will flash after a 3-second countdown. question: The flow chart illustrates the consequence of deforestation. Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features.You should write at least 150 words.
human: The supplied illustration outlines the problems of cutting forests. As we can see, there are 4 main branches and each of them describes a certain issue, caused by deforestation.According to the first branch from the left, forest destruction can lead to the state when soil becomes hard and "baked". It occurs due to the fact that heavy logging equipment compresses the soil, as the first block of the chart says. Because soil becomes "baked", rain water starts to run off which causes flooding.If we look at the remaining branches, we can see that they all lead to the same conclusion - less biodiversity. But there are three different reasons for it. The first one is soil erosion. When we cut the trees, we have fewer tree roots to support the topsoil that eventually erodes.The second reason - increased risk of burning. It is followed by the destruction of waste wood. Then we have some micro-organisms such as pioneer species that move in and initiate degradation of vegetation. And it's all resulted in less biodiversity.The last branch starts with the fact that after cutting forests we have less plants to give back moisture to air, so less moisture enters the air. This triggers less precipitation, and so, increased droughts. Plants that unable to withstand hot and dry weather die and it ends with less biodiversity.To conclude everything, the main purpose of the presented flow chart was to demonstrate the severe damage that could be caused by deforestation.
llm: The provided illustration highlights the consequences of deforestation, which can be categorized into four main issues. Each branch of the illustration describes a distinct problem caused by forest cutting.The first branch, located on the left, illustrates how forest destruction can lead to soil compaction, causing it to become hard and "baked." This occurs due to the compression of soil by heavy logging equipment, as indicated in the first block of the chart. As a result, rainwater runs off, leading to flooding.Examining the remaining branches reveals that they all converge to the same outcome: reduced biodiversity. However, there are three different underlying reasons for this consequence. The first reason is soil erosion, which happens when tree roots are no longer present to support the topsoil, leading to its erosion after trees are cut down.The second reason is the increased risk of forest fires, which is followed by the destruction of leftover wood debris. This creates an environment where micro-organisms, such as pioneer species, can thrive and initiate the degradation of vegetation, ultimately resulting in reduced biodiversity.The last branch explains that after forests are cut down, there are fewer plants to release moisture into the air, leading to reduced precipitation and increased droughts. Plants that are unable to withstand the hot and dry conditions die off, culminating in reduced biodiversity.In conclusion, the primary purpose of the presented flow chart is to illustrate the severe environmental damage that can be caused by deforestation, emphasizing the importance of preserving our forests.

However, this is the opposite tendency in the average number of days with rainfall in Canberra which slightly increases from 7 days in February to 10 days in June, July and August.To sum up, Canberra has rainy and cold winters, whilst Brisbane has rainy and warm summers.

However, a notable difference is that Canberra consistently records lower temperatures than Brisbane. Moreover, Brisbane experiences a higher average number of rainy days than Canberra for most of the year.A closer examination of the data reveals that Canberra's maximum average daily temperatures undergo a significant decline, dropping from 27°C in January to 11°C in July. In contrast, Brisbane's daily maximum temperatures fluctuate less, ranging from 28°C in January to 21°C in July. It is also worth noting that Brisbane reaches its peak maximum average daily temperature of 30°C in February, whereas Canberra records its lowest minimum average daily temperature of 2°C in June and July.The average number of days with rainfall in Brisbane decreases moderately during the winter months, from 14 days in February to 7 days in June, July, and August. Conversely, Canberra exhibits an opposite trend, with the average number of rainy days increasing slightly from 7 days in February to 10 days in June, July, and August.In summary, the data suggests that Canberra is characterized by cold and rainy winters, while Brisbane is marked by warm and rainy summers.

In contrast, the other three labor categories - industrial, sales and office, and technical - exhibited an average growth rate from 1970 to 2010.The modernization of US society and the development of urban areas transformed the labor market, with high demand for labor in technical, industrial, and service fields. Notably, the "other services" category remained an exception, as it maintained an average rate of 10% since 1970, showing little change over the years.

question: The line graph below shows the oil production and consumption in China between 1982 and 2006.Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons where relevant.
human: This line graph indicates oil production and consumption per day in China from 1982 to 2006. Clearly, the consumption doubled its production in 2006.To begin with, oil consumption started the millions of oil barrels per day for almost two, and remained the same by 1990. But, its consumption suddenly surged to about 3.7 million in 1994. Then, the number of consumption skyrocketed from 1998 and reached a peak of more than 6 million in 2006. Consequently, the consumption tripled, compared with 1982.Secondly, the production also commenced the millions of oil barrels per day around two, and increased its production to three million in 1986. In contrast, its production leveled off by 1994. Afterward, the production slightly kept going up and resulted in 3.5 million in 2006. As a result, the oil production increased, compared with 1982. But it is clear that the pace of production is quite slower than consumption.
llm: This line graph illustrates the daily oil production and consumption in China from 1982 to 2006. Notably, by 2006, consumption had surpassed production, with consumption nearly doubling production levels.Initially, oil consumption began at approximately 2 million barrels per day and remained relatively stable until 1990. However, it experienced a significant surge to around 3.7 million barrels per day by 1994. From 1998 onwards, consumption accelerated rapidly, peaking at over 6 million barrels per day in 2006. As a consequence, consumption tripled in comparison to the levels in 1982.In contrast, oil production also started at around 2 million barrels per day and increased to 3 million barrels per day by 1986. By 1994, production had stabilized. Subsequently, production continued to rise, albeit slightly, reaching 3.5 million barrels per day in 2006. While this represents an increase in production compared to 1982, it is evident that the rate of production growth is substantially slower than that of consumption.

llm: The provided map and chart offer insights into the global preferences for consuming insect products and the market prices of various food items. In stark contrast, Japan exhibits a significantly low willingness, with only 21% of its population open to the idea.The chart reveals a fascinating price hierarchy of food products. At the opposite end of the spectrum, weaver ants are the most expensive, with a price tag of $10.65 per kilogram. A clear trend emerges indicating that insects are generally less affordable than other protein sources. However, water bugs and house crickets deviate from this trend, presenting relatively more affordable options. An interesting side note is that male water bugs command a higher price than their female counterparts, underscoring the complexity of pricing within the insect food market.

question: The maps below show the development of a small fishing village and its surrounding area into a large European tourist resort.Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.
human: The map illustrates on how a fishing village with a population of 12,000 people in 1974 has been converted to a European tourist resort in 2004 which can accommodate 80,000 residents and 50,000 tourist beds.Except for the fishing village, all other places were modified.It is apparent from the map that there has been a huge loss of flora and fauna on this restructure. Dense woodland was replaced with hotels and golf course. Areas allocated for sheep and goats and olives cultivation were converted into tourist shops and farmland for harvesting fruits and vegetables to serve tourists at hotels.A portion of village, harbour and place were boats were stationed has been relocated to accommodate tourists to have a sea view.A pathway has been created from top of the mountain to the beach to facilitate tourist travel different destinations.Consequently, there has been a huge loss in habitat and probably a shift in fishermen jobs. For survival, fishermen would have taken up jobs like working in tourist shops, serving tourists at restaurant and guiding tourists.
llm: The map depicts the transformation of a small fishing village with a population of 12,000 in 1974 into a thriving European tourist resort by 2004, capable of accommodating 80,000 residents and offering 50,000 beds for tourists. This metamorphosis has resulted in significant alterations to the landscape, with the exception of the original fishing village. A notable consequence of this redevelopment is the substantial loss of flora and fauna. Dense woodlands have given way to hotels and golf courses, while areas previously dedicated to sheep and goat grazing, as well as olive cultivation, have been repurposed as tourist shops and farmland for growing fruits and vegetables to cater to the needs of hotel guests.To provide tourists with a seaside view, parts of the village, harbor, and boat stations have been relocated. Additionally, a pathway has been constructed from the top of the mountain to the beach, facilitating easier travel for tourists to various destinations within the resort. The environmental and socioeconomic impacts of this transformation are considerable. The loss of natural habitats is evident, and it is likely that the traditional livelihoods of fishermen have been disrupted. In response, former fishermen may have sought alternative employment opportunities such as working in tourist shops, serving in restaurants, or guiding tourists, highlighting the significant shift in the local economy and employment patterns.

question: The movement of people from the countryside into the cities is happening in many parts of the world, resulting in the problems, especially in cities.What are the causes of this movement, and how can it be reversedGive reasons for your answer, and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.
human: People move from the countryside into the cities. It occurs in many parts of the world, causing problems, especially in urban areas. This essay will elaborate on the causes of this movement, and the way it can be reversed from my personal standpoint.Centralization has caused this movement. All the major institutions and facilities are in the cities. Thus, people in rural areas have to sacrifice considerable time and effort to travel to urban centres. As it is also costly, people choose to move into the cities so that traveling does not consume their time. For instance, one-fifth of the total population in Korea currently lives in Seoul, the capital city of Korea. In fact, all the educational, medical, and entertainment facilities are centralized in urban areas. It can be reserved by implementing decentralization. The government has to disperse the location of the major institutions and diverse types of facilities into different districts so that people living in remote areas can also benefit.Furthermore, people in remote areas want to earn opportunities for better employment or education. As a city is a point where technologies, investments ,and professions gather, there is a better opportunity for people to get employed or educated in a improved quality. Therefore, people choose to leave the countryside. Thereby, the government can initiate the policies in which firms earn benefit when they move their head office to districts. If the firms commence moving, it will produce a great amount of employment.Conclusively, not only the government but also the businesses and institutions have to co-operate to combat problems resulting from a surge in the movement of people from the countryside into the cities.
llm: The migration of people from rural areas to cities is a widespread phenomenon that occurs in many parts of the world, leading to numerous problems, particularly in urban areas. This essay will explore the reasons behind this movement and propose potential solutions from a personal perspective.One of the primary causes of this migration is centralization, where major institutions and facilities are concentrated in cities. As a result, people living in rural areas must dedicate significant time and resources to travel to urban centers, which can be costly and time-consuming. For example, a substantial portion of Korea's population, approximately one-fifth, resides in Seoul, the capital city, where most educational, medical, and entertainment facilities are located. To reverse this trend, decentralization can be implemented, where the government disperses major institutions and facilities across different districts, making them more accessible to people living in remote areas.Additionally, people in rural areas are drawn to cities in search of better employment and educational opportunities. Cities are hubs for technology, investment, and professional development, offering improved prospects for employment and education. Consequently, individuals opt to leave rural areas in pursuit of these opportunities. To address this, the government can introduce policies that incentivize companies to relocate their headquarters to rural districts, generating a substantial number of jobs and stimulating local economies.In conclusion, it is essential that not only the government but also businesses and institutions collaborate to mitigate the problems arising from the mass migration of people from rural areas to cities. By working together, it is possible to create opportunities and improve the quality of life in rural areas, thereby reducing the allure of city life and promoting a more balanced distribution of population.

question: The number of advertisements for charities on television and the Internet seems to be increasing. What is causing this? Is this a positive or a negative development?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your knowledge or experience.You should write at least 250 words.
human: It indeed appears true that the frequency with which advertisements for charities appear both on television and the Internet seems to be increasing. There can be various explanations for this and it can be seen in both a positive and negative light.One explanation for the increase in the number of charity advertisements is that the charities themselves are becoming more aggressive in their marketing. This can also be seen in the common strategy nowadays to encourage a monthly donation, rather than a one-off donation. The increased marketing is apparent too in the increased numbers of ‘street salespeople’, who stop passersby and try to get them to commit to this monthly payment.A second reason for the increase could also be that there have been more charities started and the number of advertisements would therefore increase and become more noticeable. If these charities are all legitimate, this would mean that more help will be getting to causes that need it. The increase in charities could also be explained by a possible increase of humanitarian awareness. People might be now adopting different ideologies that take into account people in less advantageous positions.If the number of advertisements for charities has risen due to the fact that there has been a positive shift in people’s compassionate principles, this surely has to be seen as an optimistic development. If it is due to the fact that governments have been cutting back, it could be seen as a pessimistic development. In addition, if there are more charities asking for more money, this will inevitably mean that the amount of money donated will have to be more thinly spread, which would be a negative development.There could be several reasons for why there are more charity advertisements today. Whatever the reasons, as long as any money is helping people in disadvantageous positions, it must be seen as a positive development.
llm: The proliferation of charity advertisements on both television and the internet appears to be on the rise, and this trend can be viewed from multiple perspectives. There are several possible explanations for this increase, and they can be seen as both positive and negative. One possible reason for the growing number of charity advertisements is that charities are adopting more aggressive marketing strategies. This is evident in their shift towards encouraging monthly donations rather than one-time contributions. Additionally, the rise of "street salespeople" who approach pedestrians to secure monthly commitments further underscores the increased marketing efforts. Another explanation for the surge in charity advertisements could be the establishment of new charities, leading to a higher volume of ads and greater visibility. If these charities are legitimate, this would imply that more resources are being directed towards worthy causes. The growth in the number of charities might also be attributed to a heightened sense of humanitarian awareness, with people embracing ideologies that prioritize the welfare of those in less fortunate positions.If the increase in charity advertisements is a result of a positive shift in people's compassionate values, this development should be seen as optimistic. Conversely, if it is a response to government cutbacks, it could be viewed as pessimistic. Furthermore, an increase in the number of charities competing for funds could lead to a thinner distribution of donations, which would be a negative outcome.There may be multiple factors contributing to the rise in charity advertisements. Nonetheless, as long as the funds are being utilized to support those in need, this trend should be perceived as a positive development.

question: The picture below shows how a hot balloon works. Summarize the information by selecting and reporting the main features.You should write at least 150 words.
human: The imagine illustrates how a hot balloon can fly in the sky and which parts is made of.In brief, a hot ballon is composed by a basket, burner where a flame is produced to heat cool air and an envelope connected to it by a skirt and ropes. Hot air is made in order to allow the hot ballon to work.Firstly, the basket welcomes people aboard. Meanwhile, ropes allow to connect the basket to the skirt and the envelope, which is composed by few panels in a vertical lane, multiple gores and a parachute valve. This one is a self-sealing flap that allows hot air to escape a controlled rate.Secondly, Between the skirt and the basket is located a burner which is crucial for the use of the hot balloon. In fact, it has got a propane cylinder that mix this gas with cool air so that ignites a flame to heat the air inside of the envelope. As a result hot air is made, which is lighter than cool air, and allows the hot ballon to fly in the sky.
llm: The illustration shows how a hot air balloon can fly through the sky and explains its various components. In simple terms, a hot air balloon consists of a basket, a burner that produces a flame to heat the air, and an envelope connected to the basket by a skirt and ropes. The production of hot air is essential for the balloon to function.The basket is where passengers are seated. It is connected to the skirt and the envelope via ropes. The envelope is made up of several panels arranged vertically, multiple gores, and a parachute valve. The parachute valve is a self-sealing flap that allows hot air to escape at a controlled rate.The burner, located between the skirt and the basket, plays a crucial role in the operation of the hot air balloon. It features a propane cylinder that mixes the gas with cool air, igniting a flame that heats the air inside the envelope. As a result, hot air is generated, which is lighter than cool air and enables the balloon to soar through the sky.

llm: The diagram illustrates the steps to create a pizza dough, providing measurements in grams and the time required for each stage. Initially, the essential ingredients - 400g of 00 flour, 325g of water (approximately one and a half cups), and half a teaspoon of dry active yeast - are combined in a bowl. Next, the mixture is placed in a stand mixer, where it undergoes a three-stage mixing process. The first and third stages involve slow-speed mixing for 2 minutes each, while the second stage involves medium-speed mixing for 5 minutes.After mixing, the dough is left to rest until its thickness has doubled, which takes at least 2 hours. Once the dough has rested, any air bubbles are manually removed by squeezing. The resulting dough is then divided into three equal portions, either by cutting it into three equal slices or by weighing each portion to 275 grams.

question: The proportion of older people is increasing, what problems will this cause and what solutions can be suggested?
human: In many countries the proportion of older people is steadily increasing. What problems will this cause for individuals and society? Suggest some measures that could be taken to reduce the impact of ageing populations.It is true that nowadays people in industrialised nations can expect to live longer than ever before. Although there will undoubtedly be some negative consequences to this trend, societies can take steps to mitigate these potential problems.As people live longer and the populations of developed countries grow older, several related problems can be anticipated. The main issue is that there will obviously be more people of retirement age who will be eligible to receive a pension. The proportion of younger, working adults will be smaller, and governments will therefore receive less money in taxes in relation to the size of the population. In other words, an ageing population will mean a greater tax burden working adults. Further pressures will include a rise in the demand for healthcare, and the adults will increasingly have to look after their elderly relatives.There are several actions that governments could take to solve the problems described above. Firstly, a simple solution would be to increase the retirement age for working adults, perhaps from 65 to 70. Nowadays, people of this age tend to be healthy enough to continue a productive working life. A second measure would be for governments to encourage immigration in order to increase the number of working adults who pay taxes. Finally, money from national budgets will need to be taken from other areas and spent vital healthcare, accommodation and transport facilities for the rising numbers of senior citizens.In conclusion, various measures can be taken to tackle the problems that are certain to arise as the populations of countries grow older.This essay covers the task requirements, however some problems of aging population get only a brief mention. The linking of sentences in the second body paragraph is somewhat ‘mechanical’ and could have been improved. Information sequencing and organisation in paragraphs are done well. The range of vocabulary and the fluency of its use, as well as lack of errors are impressive. Overall, this is a good example of how to get Band 8 without writing a very long essay.
llm: The proportion of older individuals in many countries is steadily rising, leading to a multitude of challenges for both individuals and society as a whole. This essay will explore the potential problems associated with an ageing population and propose measures to mitigate these issues.It is undeniable that, in recent years, people in industrialized nations have experienced a significant increase in life expectancy. Although this trend is expected to have some unfavorable consequences, societies can take proactive steps to alleviate these potential problems. As the population in developed countries grows older, several interrelated issues can be anticipated. The primary concern is that there will be a substantial increase in the number of individuals of retirement age, thereby eligibility for pensions, will rise. Consequently, the proportion of working adults will decrease, resulting in lower tax revenues for governments, relative to the population size. In essence, an ageing population translates to a greater tax burden on working adults. Additional pressures include an increased demand for healthcare services, as well as the need for adults to care for their elderly relatives.To address the aforementioned problems, governments can implement several solutions. Firstly, a straightforward approach would be to raise the retirement age for working adults, potentially from 65 to 70, as individuals of this age are generally healthy enough to continue contributing to the workforce. A second measure would involve governments promoting immigration to augment the number of tax-paying working adults. Lastly, governments will need to reallocate funds from other areas in their national budgets to invest in essential healthcare, accommodation, and transportation facilities for the growing number of senior citizens.In conclusion, various strategies can be employed to tackle the problems inevitably arising from ageing populations. This essay fulfills the task requirements, albeit with some issues related to aging populations being only briefly mentioned. The connection between sentences in the second body paragraph is somewhat mechanical and could be improved. Nevertheless, the sequencing and organization of information within paragraphs are well-executed. The vocabulary range and its fluent usage, coupled with the absence of errors, are impressive. Overall, this serves as a prime example of how to attain Band 8 without crafting an excessively lengthy essay.
